chunks.text: Conscription Day is always the deadliest.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Maybe that’s why the sunrise is especially beautiful this morning—because I know it might be my last.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I tighten the straps of my heavy canvas rucksack and trudge up the wide staircase of the stone fortress I call home.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: My chest heaves with exertion, my lungs burning by the time I reach the stone corridor leading to General Sorrengail’s office.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: This is what six months of intense physical training has given me—the ability to barely climb six flights of stairs with a thirty-pound pack.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I’m so fucked.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: The thousands of twenty-year-olds waiting outside the gate to enter their chosen quadrant for service are the smartest and strongest in Navarre.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Hundreds of them have been preparing for the Riders Quadrant, the chance to become one of the elite, since birth.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I’ve had exactly six months.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: The expressionless guards lining the wide hallway at the top of the landing avoid my eyes as I pass, but that’s nothing new.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Besides, being ignored is the best possible scenario for me.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Basgiath War College isn’t known for being kind to…well, anyone, even those of us whose mothers are in command.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Every Navarrian officer, whether they choose to be schooled as healers, scribes, infantry, or riders, is molded within these cruel walls over three years, honed into weapons to secure our mountainous borders from the violent invasion attempts of the kingdom of Poromiel and their gryphon riders.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: The weak don’t survive here, especially not in the Riders Quadrant.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: The dragons make sure of that.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: You’re sending her to die!
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: a familiar voice thunders through the general’s thick wooden door, and I gasp.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: There’s only one woman on the Continent foolish enough to raise her voice to the general, but she’s supposed to be on the border with the Eastern Wing.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Mira.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: There’s a muffled response from the office, and I reach for the door handle.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: She doesn’t stand a chance.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: as I force the heavy door open and the weight of my pack shifts forward, nearly taking me down.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Shit.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: The general curses from behind her desk, and I grab onto the back of the crimson-upholstered couch to catch my balance.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Damn it, Mom, she can’t even handle her rucksack.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: I’m fine!
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: My cheeks heat with mortification, and I force myself upright.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: She’s been back for five minutes and is already trying to save me.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Because you need saving, you fool.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I don’t want this.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: I don’t want any part of this Riders Quadrant shit.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: It’s not like I have a death wish.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: I would have been better off failing the admission test to Basgiath and going straight to the army with the majority of conscripts.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: But I can handle my rucksack, and I will handle myself.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: Oh, Violet.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: Worried brown eyes look down at me as strong hands brace my shoulders.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Hi, Mira.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: She might be here
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: to say her goodbyes, but I’m just glad to see my sister for the first time in years.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Her eyes soften, and her fingers flex on my shoulders like she might pull me into a hug, but she steps back and turns to stand at my side, facing our mother.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: You can’t do this.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: It’s already done.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: Mom shrugs, the lines of her fitted black uniform rising and falling with the motion.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I scoff. So much for the hope of a reprieve. Not that I ever should have expected, or even hoped for, an ounce of mercy from a woman who’s been made famous for her lack of it.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Then undo it.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: She’s spent her whole life training to become a scribe. She wasn’t raised to be a rider.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: Well, she certainly isn’t you, is she, Lieutenant Sorrengail?
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: Well, she certainly isn’t you, is she, Lieutenant Sorrengail?
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: Mom braces her hands on the immaculate surface of her desk and leans in slightly as she stands, looking us over with narrowed, appraising eyes that mirror the dragons’ carved into the furniture’s massive legs.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I don’t need the prohibited power of mind reading to know exactly what she sees.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: At twenty-six years old, Mira’s a younger version of our mother.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: She’s tall, with strong, powerful muscles toned from years of sparring and hundreds of hours spent on the back of her dragon.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Her skin practically glows with health, and her golden-brown hair is sheared short for combat in the same style as Mom’s.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: But more than looks, she carries the same arrogance, the unwavering conviction that she belongs in the sky.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: She’s a rider through and through. She’s everything I’m not, and the disapproving shake of Mom’s head says she agrees.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I’m too short. Too frail. What curves I do have should be muscle, and my traitorous body makes me embarrassingly vulnerable.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Mom walks toward us, her polished black boots gleaming in the mage lights that flicker from the sconces.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: She picks up the end of my long braid, scoffs at the section just above my shoulders where the brown strands start to lose their warmth of color and slowly fade to a steely, metallic silver by the ends, and then drops it.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: “Pale skin, pale eyes, pale hair.” Her gaze siphons every ounce of my confidence down to the marrow in my bones.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: “It’s like that fever stole all your coloring along with your strength.”
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: Grief flashes through her eyes and her brows furrow.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: “I told him not to keep you in that library.”
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: It’s not the first time I’ve heard her curse the sickness that nearly killed her while she was pregnant with me or the library Dad made my second home once she’d been stationed here at Basgiath as an instructor and he as a scribe.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: “I love that library,” I counter.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: It’s been more than a year since his heart finally failed, and the Archives are still the only place that feels like home in this giant fortress, the only place where I still feel my father’s presence.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Spoken like the daughter of a scribe, Mom says quietly, and I see it—the woman she was while Dad was alive. Softer. Kinder…at least for her family.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: I am the daughter of a scribe.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: My back screams at me, so I let my pack slip from my shoulders, guiding it to the floor, and take my first full breath since leaving my room.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Mom blinks, and that softer woman is gone, leaving only the general.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: You’re the daughter of a rider, you are twenty years old, and today is Conscription Day. I let you finish your tutoring, but like I told you last spring, I will not watch one of my children enter the Scribe Quadrant, Violet.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: Because scribes are so far beneath riders?
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: Yes! Her customary composure slips.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: And if you dare walk into the tunnel toward the Scribe Quadrant today, I will rip you out by that ridiculous braid and put you on the parapet myself.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: My stomach turns over.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Dad wouldn’t want this!
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: Mira argues, color flushing up her neck.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I loved your father, but he’s dead, Mom says, as if giving the weather report.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: I doubt he wants much these days.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: I suck in a breath but keep my mouth shut. Arguing will get me nowhere. She’s never listened to a damned thing I’ve had to say before, and today is no different.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Sending Violet into the Riders Quadrant is tantamount to a death sentence.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: She’s not strong enough, Mom! She’s already broken her arm this year, she sprains some joint every other week, and she’s not tall enough to mount any dragon big enough to keep her alive in a battle.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: Seriously, Mira?
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: What. The. Hell.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: My fingernails bite into my palms as I curl my hands into fists.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: Are you calling me weak?
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: No.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: Just…fragile.
chunks.speaker: MIRA

chunks.text: That’s not any better.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: Dragons don’t bond fragile women. They incinerate them.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: So she’s small.
chunks.speaker: MOM

chunks.text: Mom scans me up and down, taking in the generous fit of the cream belted tunic and pants I selected this morning for my potential execution.
chunks.speaker: NARRATOR

chunks.text: I snort.
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: Are we just listing my faults now?
chunks.speaker: VIOLET

chunks.text: I never said it was a fault.
chunks.speaker: MOM
